unnormalised: Pediatrics in India has come a long way, hasn't it? I remember when my niece was born; getting her vaccinated seemed like navigating a maze. Now, there are camps organized by the govt and even local NGOs making it easier. Back then, Dr. Mehra, the pediatrician, was the only reliable source. He'd prescribe medicines like Crocin syrup for a fever and explain everything in detail.
normalised: Pediatrics in India has come a long way, hasn't it? I remember when my niece was born; getting her vaccinated seemed like navigating a maze. Now, there are camps organized by the government and even local N-G-Os making it easier. Back then, Doctor Mehra, the pediatrician, was the only reliable source. He'd prescribe medicines like Crocin syrup for a fever and explain everything in detail.

unnormalised: One thing I've noticed is the increased awareness about common childhood illnesses. Used to be, every cough and sniffle meant a trip to the doc. Now, parents are more informed about managing minor ailments at home. They know when to worry and when to just give their kids some haldi doodh and rest. Places like AIIMS Delhi have dedicated pediatric units that are constantly researching new treatments.

unnormalised: However, challenges remain. Access to quality pediatric care in rural areas is still a big issue. Many villages rely on community health workers or unqualified practitioners. And misinformation can spread like wildfire, especially through WhatsApp forwards. I once saw a message claiming that Vit C can cure every ailment, which is completely wrong.

unnormalised: Nutrition is another area that needs attention. Childhood obesity is on the rise in urban areas, while malnutrition persists in rural areas. My son's school nurse, Mrs. Singh, constantly emphasizes the importance of a balanced diet and physical activity. She even suggested reducing screen time to under 2 hrs a day.

My son's school nurse, Missus Singh, constantly emphasizes the importance of a balanced diet and physical activity. She even suggested reducing screen time to under two hours a day.

unnormalised: And let’s talk about the costs. Pediatric healthcare can be expensive, especially if your child requires specialized treatment or has chronic conditions. A consultation with a specialist at a private hospital can easily set you back Rs. 2000 or more. Thankfully, govt schemes like Ayushman Bharat are helping to make healthcare more accessible.

Thankfully, government schemes like Ayushman Bharat are helping to make healthcare more accessible.

unnormalised: Ultimately, ensuring the well-being of our children requires a collective effort. From parents and healthcare professionals to policymakers and community leaders, everyone has a role to play. Let's keep learning, keep sharing accurate information, and keep working towards a healthier future for all Indian children, especially in pediatric sub-specialties like pediatric cardiology. Remember to consult a certified medical professional for all health related ailments and don’t rely on home remedies for long periods.
